name: 2-amino-4-methoxybenzothiazole
Reason: 2-Amino-4-methoxybenzothiazole has a melting point that we can compare to by analyzing its structural components: The basic unit for this compound can be considered benzothiazole, which has a melting point around 106°C. The methoxy group (O-C(=O)c1cccc2) adds approximately +10 due to the increase in molecular weight and rigidity of the structure. The amino group (N) introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions, raising the melting point by about +20. The methoxy group also introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions, raising the melting point by about +10. The presence of two carbonyl groups generally increases the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, which can raise it by approximately +10°C each. However, 1-ethyl substitution tends to lower the melting point compared to piperazine, as it creates a more asymmetric structure, reducing the crystal lattice stability, which might decrease the melting point by approximately -10°C. Summing up these changes: Piperazine base (+106°C), two carbonyl groups (+20°C), one ethyl group (-10°C), and one methoxy group (+10°C).
